required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Clinical Study to Assess the Effects of Various Dentifrice Technologies on Dentinal Hypersensitivity
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Clinical Study to Assess the Effects of Various Dentifrice Technologies on Dentinal Hypersensitivity

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy (changes in dentinal hypersensitivity) and safety (oral soft tissue evaluation) after use of one of four dentifrices in subjects with pre-existing hypersensitivity over an 11-week period.

primary_outcome.description: The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

secondary_outcome.description: The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth.

The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

The Schiff Sensitivity Scale will be assessed for each test tooth via an evaporative air challenge. The examiner will record the Schiff Index score corresponding to the response to the air challenge. The Schiff Index Sensitivity scale is scored as follows- 0: tooth/subject did not respond to stimulus, 1: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2: tooth/subject responds to stimulus and requests discontinuation or moves form stimulus, 3: tooth/subject responds to stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful, and requests discontinuation of the stimulus. The higher the Schiff score, the more sensitive the tooth. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure. All subjects will have been on three weeks use of a marketed sodium monofluophosphate toothpaste (from week 8 to week 11).

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form.

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure.

Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure. All subjects will have been on three weeks use of a marketed sodium monofluorophosphate toothpaste (from week 8 to week 11).

outcome.title: Baseline Yeaple Probe
outcome.description: Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form.

outcome.title: Tactile Threshold
outcome.description: Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure. All subjects will have been on three weeks use of a marketed sodium monofluorophosphate toothpaste (from week 8 to week 11).

group.title: Marketed Stannous Fluoride Toothpaste
group.description: Brush twice daily Stannous fluoride toothpaste: Marketed stannous fluoride (0.454%) toothpaste

group.title: Marketed Potassium Nitrate Toothpaste
group.description: Brush Twice Daily Potassium nitrate toothpaste: Marketed potassium nitrate (5%) toothpaste

group.title: Marketed Sodium Monofluorophosphate Toothpaste
group.description: Brush Twice Daily Sodium monofluorophosphate toothpaste: Marketed sodium monofluorophosphate (0.76%) toothpaste

group.title: Experimental Dipotassium Oxalate Toothpaste
group.description: Brush Twice Daily Dipotassium oxalate toothpaste: Experimental dipotassium oxalate (3%) toothpaste

measure.title: Tactile Threshold
measure.description: Tactile Threshold will be measured using a Yeaple probe. Testing is performed beginning at 10 g. The examiner records tactile scores for responding teeth. After treatment, testing begins at 10 g and increases by 10 g to a maximum of 50 g. The higher the tactile threshold, the less sensitive the tooth. Each successive challenge increases until a "yes" response is repeated. If a second "yes" is not obtained, the force setting is increased to the next step and continued until a force is found which elicits two consecutive "yes" responses and will be recorded as the threshold on the Tactile Sensitivity Score form. The least square mean will be calculated for this measure. All subjects will have been on three weeks use of a marketed sodium monofluorophosphate toothpaste (from week 8 to week 11).

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected for all 11 weeks of the study for each intervention.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: PI should disclose plans to sponsor prior to public release.
